Step.name: Using the FSDMP
Step.html: As you begin your assessment and monitoring you will undoubtedly have questions. After conducting numerous training sessions and fielding questions from soil scientists the following questions and answers are provided.

Step.name: How do I know if I have the most recent version of the worksheet and guides?
Step.html:
The most recent versions are always posted on www.forest.moscowfsl.wsu.edu/solo

As changes are made we also forward the information to each regional soil scientist so they can disseminate through their mailing lists.

Step.name: Where are the monitoring results stored?
Step.html:
Currently monitoring results are stored on individual computers or a regional server (R1). In the future a national database will be developed for storage and access to soil monitoring data.Once the national database is developed it will assist in determining the priority of units to monitor, development of local risk-ratings, and provide validation data for determining detrimental disturbance. We will continue to update your regional soil scientist on the progress of the database.

We encourage adjacent forests to share monitoring results to build a more robust database at the local level. Once the monitoring is conducted on a forest it is immediately available for use in NEPA documents and year-end monitoring reports. Often times combining these results with BMPs can be a useful tool for working with state water control boards.

Step.name: What does forest floor impacted mean?
Step.html:
The intent of this soil monitoring attribute is to note whether or not the forest floor is in a similar condition to pre-harvest. One key finding of the North America Long-Term Soil Productivity study is that maintenance of the forest floor is key to maintaining nutrient cycling.

In addition, the forest floor reduces erosion and maintains soil moisture throughout the growing season.

It is important to note that this is just one attribute which is further characterized by answering the subsequent attributes on the form.

Step.name: Can I add additional attributes to the form?
Step.html:
Yes! There are three blank rows within the data-entry spreadsheet that allow you to select additional attributes that may be important for your location.

The results will also be calculated on these as well.

Step.name: What does "rock" mean in the soil cover attributes?
Step.html:
The rock being counted is surface rock.

Rock is a component of the soil cover attributes and reflects the composition of the soil cover present. Surface rock provides erosion control but it also can be an indicator of management induced impacts if subsurface rocks are brought to the surface.

Step.name: How do we interpret the soil cover attributes on the results page?
Step.html:
For example if the results show the proportion of bare soil is 83% then that means that 83% of the points observed have bare soil present but not that 83% of the unit is bare soil.

These proportions are characterizing the composition of the ground cover present rather than its extent.

Step.name: What happens if the point falls in a place that can not be sampled?
Step.html:
Prior to sampling you should establish a set of rules to determine if you will offset from these places.

If you can't offset and can not sample place "." in each cell for that point. This will ensure correct calculations of sample size and confidence interval.

If you can offset then complete the sampling point by filling in each attribute with "0" or "1". In addition be sure to put a note in the comment field.

For more information on this subject consult Volume II.

Step.name: How do I determine "detrimental disturbance"?
Step.html:
Currently each region has definitions for detrimental disturbance which should be used to answer this question. However, a validation protocol is being developed that will help you determine which visual class is considered detrimental on a site-specific basis.

Consult with your regional soil scientist for the most current direction.

Step.name: I have a large area or unit to sample, how do I do it?
Step.html:
There are several things to consider when developing your monitoring plan for a large area including the following:

•Stratify the unit (area) based on slope, soil type, geology, vegetation, risk, or hydrology.

•Break the unit into smaller units and randomly select a sub-sample of the smaller units.

•Coordinate with other field crews (timber cruiser, fuels) to help collect field data.

•Share resources across districts and forests to maximize data collection.

•Consult Volume II for additional details.

Step.name: When will Onsite be available?
Step.html: Onsite will be available as soon as the national soil database is completed.

Step.name: Can this monitoring be used for prescribed burning or wildfire recovery?
Step.html: Yes, the FSDMP can be used to detect changes in fire severity and long-term recovery. When using this as a monitoring tool you may see areas move over time from a class 2 or 3 to a class 1 or 0.

Step.name: How come the rut depths appear so shallow and how do I use this attribute?
Step.html:
The rut depth classes are 2.5", 5" and 7.5". These classes are important for determining changes in hydrologic function. Because this is a national protocol we were looking at depths that can begin to alter that hydrologic regime. Locally a 7.5" rut (which classifies as soil disturbance class 3) may not be detrimental to hydrologic function, but you can note this in the comment field.

It may be more important on your site to have information about compaction or burning rather than ruts and you can turn off the sample size calculation on the variable selection tab for ruts.

Keep in mind that one attribute alone does not fully characterize the soil disturbance class so it is important to fill in the entire attribute list to better understand the site.

Step.name: When should I monitor after harvest activity?
Step.html:
Monitoring should be conducted 1 to 2 years post-harvest. However, for some logging systems (winter logging) you may want to do the monitoring within the first 6 months.

If your monitoring objective is to evaluate long-term recovery you may want to resample a subset of units 3 to 5 years post-harvest.

Step.name: How do I factor in landings, system roads, and temporary roads?
Step.html: If you know the area of these large features (landings, roads,etc) you can stratify the unit to exclude these areas. First, sample the unit excluding these features. Second, measure (estimate areal extent) the area in these large features (Onsite will be useful for this) and assign a disturbance class rating. Finally, add the percentage of area in large features to your results page findings.

Step.name: How do I fill in the attribute for platy, massive, puddled?
Step.html: The objective of the monitoring form is to characterize the site and it is useful to add comments to indicate what type of soil condition is present (e.g.,platy, massive, or puddled)

Step.name: How do I fill out the form if compaction is only found in the 10-30 cm depth?
Step.html: In this category (or others based on depth e.g. ruts, massive, platy, puddled)) fill in the row that best describes where compaction is located within the soil profile. For instance if compaction is at 10-30 cm only then the section of the form with compaction would be filled in 0, 1, 0. However, if compaction is throughout the entire profile (0- >30 cm) then fill in the compaction section with all 1's.

Step.name: How do I ensure quality data?
Step.html:
There are several ways to ensure that quality data is being consistently collected.

•Have all crew members participate in the on-line training.

•Ensure crew members have copies of Volume I, II and the SDFG available in the field as a reference.

•Strictly follow the definitions of the disturbance classes.

•Have crew members identify the natural undisturbed condition for each unit prior to recording data.

•Ensure all crew members have a consistent method for collecting data which is documented.

•Have the local soil scientist conduct frequent quality assurance checks by checking field data and revisiting units with the field crew.

•Use GPS way points and track logs to ensure complete coverage of each unit.

•Be attentive to crew progress and any problems that may arise.

•Have the crew leader maintain a logbook of questions.

•Frequently review the results page to check any errors.

Step.name: Can I collect additional quantitative data during my transect?
Step.html:
Yes. Depending on your monitoring objectives you may want to add coarse woody debris transects or bulk density cores.

You can also stratify your unit by disturbance class and then collect bulk density cores to describe those conditions.

Step.name: Where should I enter data if I'm doing a Brown's transect?
Step.html: This information should be entered in the data forms for Brown's Transect and is not included in the FSDMP spreadsheet. However, for other attributes that are site specific there are three rows available in the spreadsheet.

Step.name: How do I summarize the forest floor depth?
Step.html:
On the older forms the forest floor depth had to be manually calculated to get an average. The latest form will provide an average forest floor depth and a confidence interval. The average will appear on the results page.

To analyze the effect of the depth of the forest floor, soil scientists can link their findings to benchmark soil data from their forest Soil Resource Inventory or the NRCS web soil survey. In doing so they can draw conclusions on the overall health and resilience of the site.
